title: Why tiny, uninhabited island has world's worst plastic pollution - CBS News

readable_content: - CBS News (2023-12-08): When researchers traveled to a tiny, uninhabited island in the middle of the Pacific Ocean, they were astonished to find an estimated 38 million pieces of trash washed up on the beaches. Almost all of the garbage they found on Henderson Island was made from plastic. There were toy soldiers, dominos, toothbrushes, and hundreds of hardhats of every shape, size, and color. The researchers say the density of trash was the highest recorded anywhere in the world, despite Henderson Island's extreme remoteness. The island is located about halfway between New Zealand and Chile and is recognized as a UNESCO world heritage site. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.
summary:
The information about the immense amount of plastic trash washing up on Henderson Island is concerning and highlights the serious environmental impact of plastic pollution. The presence of such a high density of plastic debris on a remote, uninhabited island underscores the urgent need for global action to address the issue of plastic waste. Banning plastic straws and other single-use plastics could be a step in the right direction to reduce the amount of plastic pollution in our oceans.
